While satire and parody are protected under the First Amendment, there are certain limitations to free speech. In copyright law, there is a fine line between parody and infringement, and the use of copyrighted material in a parody must be transformative and not simply a reproduction of the original work. Similarly, in regards to defamation, while satire and parody may be used as a defense, it must be clear that the statement is not intended to be taken as factual. 

It is important to understand that while parody and satire can be used to comment on important issues or to poke fun at individuals or entities, it is still subject to legal limitations. Overall, it is always a good idea for parody-makers to carefully consider the use of copyrighted material and to ensure that their parody is clearly identifiable as such to avoid any potential legal actions.
